content.raw:
There are many places in our code-base where gzerr and gzwarn messages use '\n' instead of std::endl. Prior to this pull request, that did not delay the message display, but with this pull request, many console messages are delayed until the program terminates. For example, open `gazebo -e bullet --verbose worlds/pr2.world` and then kill it, and you will see a bunch of messages.

It would be a pain to change every '\n' into a std::endl, so if there's an alternative, that would be nice.
content.html:
There are many places in our code-base where gzerr and gzwarn messages use '\n' instead of std::endl. Prior to this pull request, that did not delay the message display, but with this pull request, many console messages are delayed until the program terminates. For example, open gazebo -e bullet --verbose worlds/pr2.world and then kill it, and you will see a bunch of messages.

It would be a pain to change every '\n' into a std::endl, so if there's an alternative, that would be nice.

content.raw: I will add in a flush call to every output.
content.html: I will add in a flush call to every output.

content.raw: Correction. I reworked the code a bit so that stream flushing is handled by the magic of std::cout/cerr.
content.html: Correction. I reworked the code a bit so that stream flushing is handled by the magic of std::cout/cerr.

content.raw:
Ok, so there will be a `'\n'` vs. `std::endl` issue? There currently appears to be, since running the physics integration test currently causes the majority of the console messages to print after the test is finished.

This will be quite an inconvenience unless we make a gigantic pull request converting to std::endl.

content.raw: Having gazebo quiet by default means that our regression and unit tests don't output any console messages, which I find useful for debugging. Perhaps we could alter ServerFixture so that tests are verbose by default?
content.html: Having gazebo quiet by default means that our regression and unit tests don't output any console messages, which I find useful for debugging. Perhaps we could alter ServerFixture so that tests are verbose by default?

The following patch makes ServerFixture tests verbose by default, though there's still issues with '\n' vs. std::endl

diff -r 28326686325f test/ServerFixture.hh
--- a/test/ServerFixture.hh Thu Oct 24 12:01:38 2013 -0700
+++ b/test/ServerFixture.hh Thu Oct 24 15:52:48 2013 -0700
@@ -67,6 +67,7 @@
                this->serverThread = NULL;

                gzLogInit("test.log");
+               gazebo::common::Console::SetQuiet(false);
                common::SystemPaths::Instance()->AddGazeboPaths(
                    TEST_INTEGRATION_PATH);

content.raw: Sounds good. I'll add it in.
content.html: Sounds good. I'll add it in.

content.raw:
Let me explain what happen in my testing case: I was launching drcsim on top of this gazebo pull request installation using my catkin workspace. Launch the roslaunch command with atlas_v3.launch, gazebo appeared but no atlas. No a single message was displayed in the console. Checking logs I found that VRCPlugin was linked against previous gazebo libraries but ... do we really want to 'hide in a log' this kind of errors to users?

I would have expected that it was displayed on my console, more like a ```--quite``` option to keep console clean than ```--verbose``` to be able to see the errors.
content.html:
Let me explain what happen in my testing case: I was launching drcsim on top of this gazebo pull request installation using my catkin workspace. Launch the roslaunch command with atlas_v3.launch, gazebo appeared but no atlas. No a single message was displayed in the console. Checking logs I found that VRCPlugin was linked against previous gazebo libraries but ... do we really want to 'hide in a log' this kind of errors to users?

I would have expected that it was displayed on my console, more like a --quite option to keep console clean than --verbose to be able to see the errors.

content.raw:
I believe there should be no console output, unless requested. Here are my reasons:

1. It's ugly to output messages, especially when Gazebo is used in a large system like ROS.

2. A log of all messages is one central location users can go to for debugging purposes.

3. A follow-on pull request will have console in the GUI that will display error messages.

4. In the near future I'd like Gazebo to become a click-able icon that doesn't require a terminal.
content.html:
I believe there should be no console output, unless requested. Here are my reasons:

  1. It's ugly to output messages, especially when Gazebo is used in a large system like ROS.

  2. A log of all messages is one central location users can go to for debugging purposes.

  3. A follow-on pull request will have console in the GUI that will display error messages.

  4. In the near future I'd like Gazebo to become a click-able icon that doesn't require a terminal.

content.raw:
Mostly agree with this. Unless for errors. The sooner the user is able to be aware of the error, the better. Is there any change of getting the errors displayed in the console as well as written in the log? Or at least a tip on the console when an error is reported saying: "The log register some errors, please check them out".

This is specially important for system errors like mine, reporting a bad library linkage, and will end up with a working gazebo screen but a "mysteriously" not working plugin.
content.html:
Mostly agree with this. Unless for errors. The sooner the user is able to be aware of the error, the better. Is there any change of getting the errors displayed in the console as well as written in the log? Or at least a tip on the console when an error is reported saying: "The log register some errors, please check them out".

This is specially important for system errors like mine, reporting a bad library linkage, and will end up with a working gazebo screen but a "mysteriously" not working plugin.

content.raw:
occasionally I see strange characters being printed to `gzserver.log` when opening an empty world. 

`gedit` complains about character encoding and `vim` shows the unexpected characters:

e.g.

```
#!c++

[1385501054[2294865418) 85501054 ODE body foODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldLinearVel returns default of 0 DE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldForce returns default of 0 0 0
0 0
^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@[1385501054 294871070) ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldForce returns default of 0 0 0
[1385501054 294874296) 0 0
[1385501054 294880427) ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldForce returns default of 0 0 0

```

content.raw:
Aside from my proposed changes in branch console_improvements_scpeters (50a00ae, f227724), this code is looking good, though it will cause regressions in two areas:

1. No console messages for unit tests that don't use ServerFixture. Currently tests involving ServerFixture have been set to verbose, but other unit tests are quieted, unless we add code to every single unit test file. We can still get some of the diagnostic messages in Jenkins if we access these test log files (though they will have to be accessed between tests because they overwrite each other).

2. We have been using `'\n'` instead of `std::endl` in a lot of console messages, which was probably incorrect, but this pull request causes many of our messages that use `'\n'` to come out of order. We can solve this with a huge pull request, but it feels like a regression to me. The following `grep` shows over 1500 instances of `'\n'`.

~~~
$ grep -rnI '<<.*\\n.;' . | wc -l
1549
~~~
content.html:
Aside from my proposed changes in branch console_improvements_scpeters (50a00ae, f227724), this code is looking good, though it will cause regressions in two areas:

  1. No console messages for unit tests that don't use ServerFixture. Currently tests involving ServerFixture have been set to verbose, but other unit tests are quieted, unless we add code to every single unit test file. We can still get some of the diagnostic messages in Jenkins if we access these test log files (though they will have to be accessed between tests because they overwrite each other).

  2. We have been using '\n' instead of std::endl in a lot of console messages, which was probably incorrect, but this pull request causes many of our messages that use '\n' to come out of order. We can solve this with a huge pull request, but it feels like a regression to me. The following grep shows over 1500 instances of '\n'.

$ grep -rnI '<<.*\\n.;' . | wc -l
1549

We could setup a gazebo configuration file that has a parameter to control verbosity. We need this configuration file eventually for saving GUI state. The file would be a standard .ini file in `~/.config/`

I think your second point is already fixed. Messages should appear in order with `'\n'`. I'm testing now.
